content: What is the function of tagging a theorem @[simp] if its proof is by simp (with no additional simp lemmas)? If the proof is by simp, doesn't this mean that simp can already prove whatever is being added as a simp lemma? This seems to occur... 27 times in mathlib, so I presume it does something. Does it somehow teach the simplifier which route to take when simplifying (i.e. provide some performance benefit)? Or does this really teach simp to do something it couldn't otherwise?

Tagging a theorem @[simp] teaches simp how to convert the LHS to the RHS. But the by simp might be working on the whole statement at once, which is a less general ability than the one being taught by the new attribute.
In particular simp has some a = b \iff c = d facts.
Do these 27 cases satisfy some exception in the simp linter? Because usually a @[simp] ... := by simp would be flagged by the linter, no?
No, the linter is actually looking to see if the LHS already simplifies.
